column1: Rio Rancho (Spanish: Río Rancho) is the largest city and economic hub of Sandoval County
column2: part of the expansive Albuquerque Metropolitan Area
column3: in the U.S. state of New Mexico. A small portion of the city extends into northern Bernalillo County. It is the third-largest and also one of the fastest expanding cities in New Mexico. As of the 2010 census
column4: Rio Rancho had a population of 87
column5: 521. The name Rio Rancho derives from Los Ranchos (the ranches) that stretched along the Rio Grande in the Albuquerque Basin

column1: The great majority of Rio Rancho was originally part of the Town of Alameda Grant
column2: which was founded by Spanish settlers in 1710. By the early 20th century
column3: much of the land grant had been sold to land investment companies. Amrep Corporation purchased 55
column5: 000 ha) in 1961 and turned the land into a housing development called "Rio Rancho Estates"
column6: with the first families moving in the early 1960s. Amrep contracted with Ezio Valentini
column7: one of the original developers of Cape Coral
column9: to design and implement a unique marketing plan to conduct land-sales
column10: dinner-party program in northern states to open offices in 14 states. The population grew ten-fold between 1970 and 1980 and the City of Rio Rancho was incorporated in 1981. The opening of a large Intel Corporation plant in 1981 had a major economic impact on the city.

column2: Rio Rancho has taken steps to become more independent from neighboring Albuquerque
column3: including the establishment of separate school and library systems and attempts to attract businesses to the area. The city's latest project is the Downtown City Centre development that includes a new city hall building
column4: a new University of New Mexico West and Central New Mexico Community College campus
column5: as well as the Santa Ana Star Center. The arena opened in October 2006. City Hall opened in September 2007.

column1: Rio Rancho is located at 35°17'10" North
column3: -106.670660). It lies in the Albuquerque Basin to the west of the Rio Grande
column4: which bounds the northeast corner of the city. An escarpment lies to the west of the city limit.

column1: Rio Rancho is bordered by Albuquerque to the south
column2: the Santa Ana Indian Reservation to the north
column3: and Bernalillo and Corrales to the east.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau

column1: Rio Rancho is in an arid climate due to its location in the rain shadow of the Sandia Mountains to the east and the Continental Divide to the west. Rio Rancho receives 8.90 inches of precipitation annually on average
column2: although the western portion of the city receives slightly more rain and snowfall due to its higher elevation than the more densely-developed eastern portion of Rio Rancho.

column1: The Intel Corporation is by far the largest employer in Rio Rancho. The services
column2: retail
column3: and government sectors are also major components of the local economy.

column1: Rio Rancho is the site of Intel's Intel Fab 11X
column2: one of the largest semiconductor fabrication plants in the world. The fully automated
column3: $2 billion facility opened in 2002 and was the first Intel plant to manufacture 300 mm silicon wafers
column4: which can hold almost twice as many chips as the standard 200 mm wafers. Fab 7
column7: but is being converted into a test facility.

column2: Rio Rancho became the first U.S. city to offer citywide voice-over-WiFi (VoWiFi) service
column3: although many of its residents complained that the service did not live up to their expectations.Several call centers call Rio Rancho home. Walmart opened in early summer of 2006 in Rio Rancho

column1: Rio Rancho is home to the Albuquerque metro area's only oldies-format radio station
column2: KDSK (AM)
column3: having moved into the Rio Rancho market in March 2015 and having licensed its newest FM signal

column13: serves the entire Albuquerque metro area along with six counties in central and western New Mexico.

column1: The weekly Rio Rancho Observer is the local newspaper
column2: while Rio Ranchoans also have access to television and radio broadcasts from Albuquerque
column3: as well as the daily newspaper Albuquerque Journal
column4: along with its localized weekly version the Rio West.

column1: Rio Rancho is also served by a government-access television channel available only through the city's only cable television provider Cable ONE. This channel shows all of the government meetings multiple times.

column2: ABQ RIDE
column3: operates a bus route (251 Albuquerque-Rio Rancho Rail Runner Connection) connecting Rio Rancho with the New Mexico Rail Runner Express station at Journal Center.

column2: ABQ RIDE extended two additional routes (96 Crosstown Commuter and 155 Coors Blvd)
column3: and introduced an additional route (551 Jefferson/Paseo Del Norte Express) into Rio Rancho. The northern terminus of these routes is at Southern Blvd and Unser Blvd.

column1: The Rio Metro Regional Transportation District operates Rio Transit
column2: a door-to-door paratransit service for senior citizens 55 years of age and older
column3: and disabled adults 18 years of age and older
column4: for residents of Rio Rancho. The service is operated out of the Meadowlark Senior Center
column5: and provides service Monday-Friday from 7:30 am to 3:00 pm. Riders must register with the service prior to using it. Rio Metro RTD also operates a commuter bus route serving the Enchanted Hills neighborhood in Rio Rancho. This service connects residents of Enchanted Hills to the US 550 New Mexico Rail Runner station and provides service during the morning and evening commutes. Rio Metro Bus connections are available at the US 550 Rail Runner station for Zia Pueblo
column8: and Jemez Springs. A Rio Metro commuter bus route provides service to and from the Cuba NM area
column9: with a Park and Ride designated at Home Depot
column10: which is located near the corner of NM 528
column11: NM 550. Rio Metro's website and schedules may be viewed at: www.riometro.org

column1: Rio Rancho was home to the New Mexico Scorpions minor-league ice hockey team
